while everywhere I look on the scratchy hillsides
shadows seem to grow shoulders.

But his big, round music, after all,
is too breathy to last.
You do not have to be good.

and the old couple,
shaken with understanding,
bowed down—

Airy and shapeless thing,
it needs
the metaphor of the body,
lime and appetite,
the oceanic fluids;

So, it's over.
In the pine-crown
he makes his nest,
he's done all he can.

Softly he boomed,
and then again, and again, and then was gone,
and not once did we think of the god
of plunge and blood, of iron mouths.

Evenings out there on the plains
when sunset donated farms
that yearned so far to the west that the world
centered there and bowed down.

You aren’t much, I said
one day to my reflection
in a green pond,
and grinned.

On the far shore
a white bird is standing
like a white candle—

But the seed
has been planted, and when has happiness ever
required much evidence to begin
its leaf-green breathing?

The inventor is like the hunter—each
in the crease and spasm of the thing about to be done
is lost in his work.

All night I heard the small kingdoms
breathing around me, the insects,
and the birds who do their work in the darkness.

and what a rebellion
to leap into it
and hold on,
connecting everything,

the past to the future—
which is of course the miracle—
which is the only argument there is
against the sea.
Her child leaps among the flowers,

Later, in the kitchen, I saw the stones
like torn-out tongues
embedded in the honeyed centers.

sponging up and reflecting,
so brilliantly,
as it has for centuries,
the sun's fire.

I want to believe I am looking
into the white fire of a great mystery.

So, it's over.
In the pine-crown
he makes his nest,
he's done all he can.
Farms to both sides shook, bankrupt, in the wind.

I think of the blueberry fields, the blackberry tangles,
the cranberry bogs.
to love what is mortal;

Tell me about despair, yours, and I will tell you mine.
Meanwhile the world goes on.

and to do this
I will go indoors to my desk—
I will sit in my chair—
I will look back
into the lost morning

until the white snow is written upon
in large, exuberant letters,

I think of this every morning
as the east begins
to tear off its many clouds
of darkness,

When I began to eat
things happened.

And the gods smiled, as they vanished,
clapping their great wings.

just
as the pink moccasin flowers
are rising.

Later, I will consider
what I have seen—
what it could signify—
what words of adoration I might
make of it,

and that one is a slumped purse
full of its own
unstoppable decay.

while all around me the lilies
are breaking open again
from the black cave
of the night.

just
as the pink moccasin flowers
are rising.

One evening
I met the mango.
At first there were four or five of them
in a bowl.

This morning I watched
the pale green cones of the rhododendrons
opening their small pink and red blouses—

I'd stop just before going into a house
and be an emperor for a minute
And did you see it, finally, just under the clouds—

Not one can manage a single sound, though the blue jays
carp and whistle all day in the branches, without
the push of the wind.

Because, properly
attended to, delight, as well as havoc, is suggestion.

And to tell the truth I don't want to let go of the wrists
of idleness, I don't want to sell my life for money,
I don't even want to come in out of the rain.

the white ribbons
of their song
into the air.

to hold it against your bones knowing
your own life depends on it;

not one page
was less to me than fascinating
discursive full of cadence

But now already the loved ones gather
Under the dome of welcome,

Which is the only way to love, isn't it?
This isn't a playground, this is
earth, our heaven, for a while.

The ants bore into the peony bud and there is a dark
pinprick well of sweetness.

over and over announcing your place
in the family of things.

and I want
to live my life all over again, to begin again,
to be utterly
wild.

The white, scrolled
wings of the tumbling water
I never could have
imagined.

The domed head rose above the water, white
as a spill of milk.

as with a match,
which is lit, and bright,
but does not hurt
in the common way,

Each bee entered
the frills of a flower to find

the sticky fountain, and if some dust
spilled on the walkways of the petals
and caught onto their bodies,

two strangers
who were,
it soon appeared,
not men at all,
but gods.

Meanwhile the sun and the clear pebbles of the rain
are moving across the landscapes,

but for this alone
the gods loved them
and blessed them—

We left the car and wandered through a field,
Three ladies pausing in indifferent space.

At night, sometimes,
they slip between the pink lobes
of the moccasin flowers and lie there until dawn,

Running here running there, excited,
hardly able to stop, he leaps, he spins

Airy and shapeless thing,
it needs
the metaphor of the body,
lime and appetite,
the oceanic fluids;

maybe that is what it means, the beauty
of the blue shark cruising toward the tumbling seals.

I think of summer with its luminous fruit,
blossoms rounding to berries, leaves,
handfuls of grain.

Last night the owl bunched in the tree
outside our window.

Common sense mutters:
it can’t be true, it must be somebody’s
runaway dog. But the seed
has been planted,

And in the evening
the piled firewood shifts a little,
longing to be on its way.

and, after all,
even if we came by some miracle
upon a language which we both knew,

like the rain pelting the trees, like a waterfall
nifing down the black ledges?

to send up the first
signal—a white fan
streaked with pink and violet,
even green.

at night
in the black branches,
in the morning
in the blue branches
of the world.

By now the hawk has flown five miles
at least,
dazzling whoever else has happened
to look up.

what is it I might say
there in the orange light of early morning,
in the owl’s resting time,
that would have any pluck and worth in it?—

Finally, I noticed enough.
All around me in the forest
the white moths floated.

Because, properly
attended to, delight, as well as havoc, is suggestion.

an invisible line
upon which their iridescence caught fire
as the sun caught them, sliding down.

Airy and shapeless thing,
it needs
the metaphor of the body,
lime and appetite,
the oceanic fluids;

But what in this world
is perfect?

the hard knife-edged love
for the warm river of the I, beyond all else;
But it seems impossible.

Not one can manage a single sound, though the blue jays
carp and whistle all day in the branches, without
the push of the wind.

When I set it down, it hurried
along the tideline

of the sea,
which was slashing along as usual,
shouting and hissing
toward the future,

turning its back
with every tide on the past,

Who can say,
is it a snowy egret
or a white flower
standing

at the glossy edge
of the lily-
and frog-filled pond?

What matters
is that, when I saw them,
I saw them
as through the veil, secretly, joyfully, clearly.

One evening
I met the mango.
At first there were four or five of them
in a bowl.

forty years
and again this morning as always
I am stopped as the world comes back
wet and beautiful

but for this alone
the gods loved them
and blessed them—

an invisible line
upon which their iridescence caught fire
as the sun caught them, sliding down.

I can hardly believe
their lapped light crowding
the black,
mid-summer ponds.

and, being the color of snow, catching the sun
so they were, in part at least, golden.
What blazes the trail is not necessarily pretty.

It was the sheer, dense wall
of blind stone
without a pinch of hope

for forty years
the sheets of white paper have
passed under my hands
and I have tried
to improve their peaceful
emptiness
You kneel beside it.

and to fly, for the first time,
in their sea-green helmets,
with brisk, metallic tails—

Traveling at thirty thousand feet, we see
How much of earth still lies in wilderness

forty years
and again this morning as always
I am stopped as the world comes back
wet and beautiful

Oh, I could not have said it better
myself.

to be more than pure light
that burns
where no one is—
What blazes the trail is not necessarily pretty.

I was standing
at the edge of the field—
